title: NTSB Suspends Most Investigations Because of Employee Furloughs
summary: More than 90% of the safety board's staff remains off the job due to partial government shutdown. Employee furloughs have forced the National Transportation Safety Board to suspend practically all accident investigations and continue to prevent officials from even determining whether future probes of specific crashes may be warranted, according to information released by the agency Friday.

title: Stocks Climb Higher As Fears of Economic Slowdown Subside
summary: Economic data, signs of easing trade tensions, and a batch of upbeat earnings help lift major indexes. U.S. stocks climbed Friday to notch their fourth consecutive week of gains as the fears of an economic slowdown that gripped markets in December seem to have subsided.

title: Foxconn Falls Short of Job-Creation Target in Wisconsin
summary: Apple supplier had 182 employees at end of 2018, but needed 260 to claim tax credit for year. Foxconn Technology Group, which is building a $10 billion plant in Wisconsin in exchange for nearly $4 billion in state and local incentives, fell short of the minimum number of jobs it was required to create in 2018 to claim state-job creation tax credits, the company said Friday.

title: Two Snap Executives Pushed Out After Probe Into Inappropriate Relationship
summary: The company's head of global security allegedly had inappropriate relationship with a contractor. Snap Inc. in recent weeks pushed out two senior executives after an investigation found that one of them had allegedly engaged in an inappropriate relationship with an outside contractor, according to people familiar with the matter.

summary: Emergency vehicles get stuck on streets that have been narrowed to promote walking and bicycling.. Renee Khoury was in the kitchen when she heard a scream. She ran outside and found her 65-year-old mother, Rebecca, sprawled on the sidewalk with a compound fracture in her left leg. Renee called 911 then comforted her mom as best she could.

title: For Sanity's Sake, Delete Your Account
summary: 'The Lord knoweth the thoughts of man, that they are vanity.'. One Saturday morning last fall, I sat down at my desk and deleted my Twitter account.

title: Big Names Bake a Climate Pie in the Sky
summary: They mean well, but eminent economists are pushing an unreal 'carbon dividend' plan.. An impressive list of names endorse a carbon dividend proposal published in The Wall Street Journal this week. They include 27 Nobel Prize winners plus former Treasury secretaries, Federal Reserve chairmen and White House economists.

title: To End the Shutdown, Try Thinking Big on Immigration
summary: Both parties are to blame for this embarrassing impasse. Yet a sensible solution may be possible.. As the U.S. government shutdown approaches the one-month mark, one thing has become abundantly clear: Few politicians in Washington-Republican or Democrat, in Congress or the White House-consider the best interest of the country a priority. The fight is all about politics, partisanship and power.

title: Gizmodo Media Group Settles Defamation Lawsuits Led by Charles Harder
summary: Blog publisher claimed the litigation was meant to harass journalists, which Mr. Harder denied.. Gizmodo Media Group has settled defamation lawsuits brought by clients of lawyer Charles J. Harder, litigation that the blog publisher has claimed were meant to intimidate journalists.

title: Dollar Rises on Strong Economic Data
summary: Report showed output at U.S. factories grew 1.1% last month, the biggest gain since February. The dollar rose Friday, boosted by strong U.S. economic data.

title: Fed's Brainard Says Prolonged Political Uncertainty Could Weigh on Economic Activity
summary: Fed governor says U.S. labor market is healthy, but there are negative threats to growth. Federal Reserve Governor Lael Brainard said she is worried growing political uncertainty could weigh on consumer and business confidence, eventually crimping U.S. economic growth, in an interview that aired Friday evening.

title: UNC Defends Admissions in Suit Alleging Unfair Racial Preferences
summary: Group suing Chapel Hill clashes with school over how much race matters in admissions. The University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill defended itself against allegations that its undergraduate admissions process violates Supreme Court precedents by giving too much weight to applicants' race and failing to thoroughly implement other approaches to student-body diversity, according to court documents filed by both sides on Friday.

title: Colombia Pins Police Bombing on Marxist Rebels, Commanders in Venezuela
summary: Authorities say attacker was with insurgency ELN, plan to charge commanders they say operate in Venezuela. BOGOTÁ, Colombia-The Colombian government on Friday accused a Marxist rebel group of planning a car bombing that killed 21 and said it would press charges against guerrilla commanders believed to operate from neighboring Venezuela.

title: Another Caravan Crosses Mexican-Guatemalan Border
summary: Latest group of desperate Central Americans prompts another call from Trump for a border wall. TAPACHULA, Mexico-Some 1,500 Central Americans forced their way across Mexico's southern border early Friday and began their trek north toward the U.S. in the first migrant caravan of the year, stoking the heated political debate in the U.S. over a border wall.

title: 'Wasteland' Review: Ghosts of the Great War
summary: Horror in fiction and film took on greater prominence in the wake of World War I.. 'Après la guerre," according to a song popularized by the revue "Hullo, America," which debuted on the London stage in November 1918, "there'll be a good time everywhere." The difficulties that the writers and artists of the postwar era had in assimilating the horrors of Flanders into mainstream culture were twofold. First came that understandable, and to a large extent escapist, search for a "good time." Following in its wake came a gradual realization that the events of 1914-18 had been so traumatic for the people caught up in them that it was all but impossible to address them head-on.

title: Morgan Stanley CEO Earned $29 Million in 2018
summary: Bank chief James Gorman's compensation rose 7% from the previous year. Morgan Stanley Chief Executive James Gorman received a compensation package valued at about $29 million in 2018, a 7% raise from the $27 million he earned a year ago, according to a Friday securities filing.

title: Shutdown, Trade Tensions Weigh on U.S. Households
summary: The latest University of Michigan index is a sign that Americans could pull back on discretionary spending. Fears over the global economy are weighing on American households even though demand for factory goods remains solid.

title: Trump Administration Sets Final Rules for New Business Tax Deduction
summary: Treasury rejected requests from real-estate settlement agents, Major League Baseball team owners, writers and physical therapists, who all wanted more favorable rules. The Trump administration set final rules for a new deduction that will provide significant savings for many business owners, providing more clarity for real-estate owners and service-industry businesses.

title: Tesla to Slash More Jobs in Effort to Lower Model 3 Price
summary: Elon Musk says cutting staff by 7% is part of an effort aimed at selling the Model 3 sedan for less. Tesla Inc . plans to eliminate 7% of its full-time workforce, the auto maker's second round of job cuts in a year as it tries to maintain profitability while lowering the price of its Model 3 sedan.

title: State Street Is Cutting 1,500 Jobs
summary: Custody bank aims to trim some $350 million in expenses this year. State Street Corp. said Friday it would shed about 1,500 employees, a new sign that the asset-management industry's struggles are rippling through the rest of Wall Street.

summary: Shares of metals producers have lagged behind the broader market for years. Deals and activist campaigns at mining companies are picking up, but it may not be enough to rekindle investor enthusiasm for the group.

title: Schlumberger Says Shale Boom is Slowing
summary: CEO of oil-field service company Schlumberger warns of 'tough year in North America'. U.S. shale production is poised to slow down this year as drillers reduce their budgets in response to lower oil prices, the head of the world's largest oil-field services company said Friday.

title: U.S. Government Bonds Decline as Risk Sentiment Improves
summary: Strong economic data and signs of easing trade tensions lift yields. U.S. government-bond prices fell Friday after strong economic data and signs of a thaw in trade tensions contributed to an improvement in risk sentiment.

title: Sears and Its Creditors Can Sue Lampert, ESL Over Past Deals
summary: Past deals potentially under dispute include the spinoff of Lands' End and of much of its most valuable real estate into Seritage. title: Oil Reaches Eight-Week High As Production Falls
summary: Slowing crude output, optimistic signs on U.S.-China trade buoy oil prices. · Oil prices rose to an eight-week high on Friday, bolstered by hopes for a resolution to the U.S.-China trade dispute and signs of slowing global crude production.

title: U.S. Union Membership Rate Declined in 2018
summary: Decrease in state-employee union membership could reflect early impact of June Supreme Court ruling. The overall rate of union membership in the U.S. fell last year, largely reflecting a decline in the rate of state employees' unionization, according to the latest Labor Department data.

summary: Move comes amid renewed scrutiny of sexual-abuse allegations against the R&B artist. Pop singer R. Kelly and Sony Corp.'s RCA Records label are parting ways, amid renewed scrutiny of sexual-abuse allegations against the R&B artist.

title: A Parkland, Fla., Father's Lonely Crusade
summary: There were so many warning signs in this case that were ignored by the authorities. The police, hampered by political correctness, failed to act.. Regarding Tunku Varadarajan's "The Weekend Interview with Andrew Pollack: A Parkland Father's Quest for Accountability" (Jan. 12): Parkland father Andrew Pollack is right when he blames political correctness for the Marjory Stoneman Douglas High School killings in Parkland, Fla.

title: Dealing Wisely With the Young, Picky Eater
summary: Hunger will break the strongest-willed child provided parents themselves aren't picky, guilt-ridden and permissive caretakers.. Regarding Jennifer Traig's "The Making of the Picky Eater" (Review, Jan. 12): I lamented to my pediatrician in the 1960s that our still-in-a-highchair girl was pointing her tiny finger at the pantry and demanding to eat only peanut butter. He asked me whether she was climbing out of the chair and getting it herself. My meek and guilty "no" was followed by one or two days of her self-induced fast, amid some tears from her and me. This ultimately led to her eating anything and everything, including raw oysters and sushi.

title: They Are Banging Heads Against the Wall
summary: Democratic Sen. Mark Warner's criticism of President Trump's deal-making skills elides the obvious distinction between the businessman and the politician.. Democratic Sen. Mark Warner's criticism of President Trump's deal-making skills ("Here's How You Make a Deal, Mr. President," op-ed, Jan. 16) elides the obvious distinction between businessmen and politicians. Businessmen negotiate and compromise because they share the same objective: to make as much money as possible. Sadly, in politics as practiced today, the objective isn't money or even the common good, but power, which is a zero-sum game. There is no shared objective, hence the stalemate.

title: Rihanna and LVMH Team Up to Create a Luxury Fashion Label
summary: The new line is expected to launch in coming months with ready-to-wear clothing, handbags and accessories. PARIS-Rihanna has used her army of social-media followers to build big businesses selling cosmetics, lingerie and sportswear.

title: Airbnb Has Held Talks to Buy Hotel Tonight
summary: A deal would give the home-sharing company more inventory and help it move into hotel bookings.

title: De Blasio Lawyers Say Change for Elite Schools Isn't Biased Against Asian-Americans
summary: Mayor seeks geographic diversity, court papers argue; lawsuit sees discrimination against high-achieving Asian-Americans. Lawyers for Mayor Bill de Blasio said in new court papers that his effort to diversify New York City's elite public high schools isn't rooted in bias against Asian-Americans, and asked a federal judge to let the plan go forward for this spring's admissions cycle.

title: Copper Climbs on Trade Hopes
summary: Prices are still down 17% from their June four-year highs. Copper prices rose for the seventh time in the past nine sessions on Friday, lifted by optimism that the U.S. and China will be able to reach a trade agreement and support global growth.

title: German Forklift Maker Kion Plans U.S. Expansion to Avoid China Tariffs

title: Approvals of New Prescription Drugs at Risk in Shutdown
summary: FDA has relied on user fees paid by the pharmaceutical industry to keep the approval process on track, but that money will run out soon. The Food and Drug Administration is set to run out of money early next month to evaluate new prescription drugs if the government shutdown continues, potentially slowing the release of new therapies including cancer treatments.

title: The Chiefs Are Football's Golden State Warriors
summary: The Warriors changed basketball with Stephen Curry and the 3-point line. The Chiefs have Patrick Mahomes and are exploiting football's passing boom unlike anyone else.. The Golden State Warriors built a dynasty based on a mathematical fact so rudimentary it's obvious to preschoolers: Three points are more than two. This elementary idea catalyzed a revolution-and the analytics of efficient decision-making overtook NBA strategy.

title: Lilly's Sarcoma Drug Combo Proves Ineffective in Trials

title: How George Lucas Created 'Star Wars'
summary: The archives of the original trilogy show the evolution of Darth Vader, Boba Fett and more denizens of that galaxy far, far away. What was going through George Lucas's mind when he created the original "Star Wars" trilogy? A new book, "The Star Wars Archives, Episodes IV-VI" (Taschen, $200), by the film historian Paul Duncan, aims to answer that question. Mr. Duncan explores the filmmaker's vision through archival materials, such as Mr. Lucas's idea of a man-and-machine hybrid in a poster concept featuring Darth Vader. The book includes on-set photos, including one in which David Prowse, the actor inside Vader's armor, is seen towering behind Princess Leia Organa (Carrie Fisher) without the villain's iconic mask. Throughout, Mr. Duncan says, Mr. Lucas kept one aim in mind: "What life lessons can you teach 12-year-olds in a way they can understand?" Alexandra Wolfe

summary: OPEC and its allies have published specific quotas to bolster confidence in the output cuts that went into effect this month, but there are reasons to doubt the cartel's resolve to deepen the cuts. summary: Trump had revealed details of her travel and denied her use of military plane. summary: Genetically altered animal organs may one day replace human donors-whose extraordinary generosity should be cherished. summary: Born-again Christian applied faith to business and ministered to disgraced Nixon aide Charles Colson. Thomas Phillips's life was a story of immigrant success that catapulted him from a precarious childhood in Istanbul to the top job at a Massachusetts-based maker of missiles, Raytheon Co.

title: The Secret Power of the Children's Picture Book
summary: Even infants get profound cognitive and behavioral benefits from sharing a vivid story. Millions of people-perhaps you're one of them-have watched viral videos of a Scottish granny collapsing in laughter while she reads to a baby. Comfortable on a sofa with her grandson, Janice Clark keeps cracking up as she tries to read "The Wonky Donkey" and, in a second video recorded a few months later, "I Need a New Bum."

title: Fed's Williams: Now Is Time for Fed to Show 'Prudence, Patience and Good Judgment'
summary: If the economy weakens 'I will adjust my policy views accordingly,' New York Fed president says. SOMERSET, N.J.-New York Fed President John Williams said Friday what happens with short-term interest rates and the central bank's balance-sheet drawdown will be driven this year by how the economy performs.

title: First Priest Arrested in New Jersey Sex-Abuse Investigation
summary: State attorney general's office launched the task force in September. A New Jersey priest was arrested and charged with multiple counts of sexual assault of a child between the ages of 14 and 17, in the first criminal case brought by the state's task force examining abuse in the Catholic Church, the attorney general's office said Thursday.

title: 'All the Lives We Ever Lived' Review: Catching Hold of Vital Moments
summary: A writer's tribute to her late father and a paean to her favorite book, Virginia Woolf's "To the Lighthouse.". Katharine Smyth pulls off a tricky double homage in her beautifully written first book, a deft blend of memoir, biography and literary criticism that's a gift to readers drawn to big questions about time, memory, mortality, love and grief. "All the Lives We Ever Lived" is a tribute both to Ms. Smyth's father-who died in 2006 following a long battle with cancer and longer slide into alcoholism-and to a favorite novel, which helped her to better "read" her life, and his.

title: Shocks Are Piling up at Tesla
summary: Tesla still needs more volume and manufacturing improvements to be able to produce the $35,000 version of the Model 3. Tesla's long-term growth story is running on a low battery.

summary: Monday's vote is a bid to end decades of armed revolt by extremists. MARAWI, Philippines-In the crumbling concrete ruins of this city laid waste by a battle with Islamic State-linked militants, thousands of still homeless people cling to hope that a vote on self-rule will lay a path for lasting peace in one of Southeast Asia's worst breeding grounds for extremism.

title: UVA to Set Up School of Data Science With $120 Million Gift

summary: U.S. officials have criticized EU for dragging its feet on trade talks in the hope of waiting out the Trump administration. BRUSSELS-The European Union made its opening bid in trade talks with the U.S., outlining a narrow goal of slashing tariffs on industrial goods, including motor vehicles, that sets the bloc on a collision course with Washington's broader agenda.

title: Fiction: They Fall to Earth, We Know Not Where
summary: Sam Lipsyte looses a quiver full of satirical arrows, most of which miss their targets.. Norm Macdonald once noted about the talk show "Real Time With Bill Maher" that the comedians invited on to debate the week's news always want to play it straight, while the policy experts want to tell jokes. I've thought about this reversal a lot, as punditry and entertainment have become so weirdly intertwined that we treat the political commentariat as though they were a troupe of performance artists and then expect wisdom from nightclub comics. Remember the think pieces claiming that our leading public intellectuals were people like Amy Schumer, Joe Rogan and Louis C.K.? (Pre-disgrace Louis C.K., of course. We don't think he's so clever anymore.)

title: Best-Selling Books, Week Ending Jan. 12
summary: With data from NPD BookScan.

title: Indonesia to Grant Early Release to Radical Islamic Cleric
summary: Spiritual leader for Jemaah Islamiyah inspired some of the country's deadliest terrorist attacks. JAKARTA, Indonesia-An elderly radical Islamic cleric who inspired some of Indonesia's deadliest terrorist attacks, including the Bali bombings in 2002, will be released from prison ahead of schedule, President Joko Widodo said Friday.

title: 'Tigerland' Review: Playing the Game Their Way
summary: A chronicle of triumph and tumult at a segregated Ohio high school in the late 1960s.. Here are the raw materials of a classic American story: an all-black high school in the Midwest; the first black high-school principal in the city's history; two white coaches, in basketball and baseball; and a masterly playmaker who refuses to cut his Afro hair style to suit the sensibilities of white fans. The cultural moment is 1968-69-that is to say, a time of rough passage in our civic life: Vietnam, assassinations, countercultural stirrings, urban upheaval. And amid it all, triumph: two wildly improbable and wildly cheered state sports championships.

title: 'Last Boat Out of Shanghai' Review: Gone With the Wind
summary: An estimated one million people fled through the port city around the time the People's Republic of China was founded in 1949.. When it became clear, in the late 1940s, that Mao Zedong's Communist forces would defeat Chiang Kai-shek's Nationalist forces, more than a few Chinese residents of Shanghai greeted this news with joy and looked forward to a break from rule by a corrupt, autocratic government beholden to the United States. By contrast many foreigners in the city-European and American merchants and missionary families had been there since the mid-1800s-viewed the prospect of Communist Party rule with alarm. So, too, did many local Chinese, especially those of middling and higher social status.

title: 'Unexampled Courage' Review: Showing America the Way
summary: Nothing in Harry Truman's background suggested that the president would play a role in addressing racism in America.. Isaac Woodard served in the Pacific theater during World War II, winning a battle star for unloading ships under enemy fire in New Guinea. Mustered out of the Army in February 1946, the 26-year-old African-American was still in uniform when he boarded a Greyhound bus in Augusta, Ga., on his way home to South Carolina. When Woodard asked the white driver to use the rest room at an upcoming stop, the driver rudely dismissed him. Woodard stood up for himself, telling the driver, "God damn it, talk to me like I am talking to you. I am a man just like you." The bus driver stopped the bus in Batesburg, S.C., and called for the police. Two officers arrived and pulled Woodard off the bus; one of them brutally assaulting him, grinding the butt end of his night stick into Woodard's eye sockets, rendering him blind in both eyes.

title: 'Supreme Injustice' Review: The High Court and Slavery
summary: A legal historian contends that Justices John Marshall, Joseph Story and Roger Taney viewed opposition to slavery as a threat to the nation's fragile constitutional and political order.. When the Framers gathered in Philadelphia in 1787 to form a new national government, slavery was, as historians have often remarked, the proverbial witch at the christening. Although the new federal constitution never once mentioned slavery directly, preferring euphemisms such as "other Persons," its very fabric was shot through with provisions designed to placate slaveholding interests. Slavery was so deeply embedded in American life that of the nation's first 12 presidents, only two-New Englanders John Adams and his son John Quincy Adams-never owned slaves. Even Harriet Beecher Stowe, author of the great anti-slavery novel "Uncle Tom's Cabin," thought nothing of renting two young slaves to help with the childrearing tasks when she lived in the border town of Cincinnati. It is a legacy that remains with the nation to this day.

title: Book Review: Building a Better Mouse
summary: Mickey Mouse had two fathers: idea man Walt Disney and the animator-character designer Ub Iwerks.. Benedikt Taschen, the Cecil B. DeMille of publishers, produces books on an epic scale. Extraordinary in size and weight, with high-quality production values and an eclectic array of subject matter ranging from art, films and photography to fashion, pugilism and sex (among other topics), Taschen books are immersive events, overwhelming spectacles and luxury collectible objects-a refutation of the supposed triumph of pixels over paper.

title: Children's Books: Speaking Plainly About Slavery
summary: Works that give young readers sound, if often unsettling, glimpses of their country's past.. It was once possible for children to grow up aware in only the vaguest way that slavery was woven into the earliest chapters of the American story. That is no longer the case. Decades of scholarship and civil-rights activism, not to mention the creative work of writers and artists, have made the "peculiar institution" part of children's common understanding.

title: Supermen and Wonder Women
summary: Artists reimagine two comic-book heroes with admiration and irreverence. In the exhibition "Men of Steel, Women of Wonder," which opens Feb. 9 at the Crystal Bridges Museum of American Art in Bentonville, Ark., Superman and Wonder Woman take on many unexpected new roles. Americans see these comic-book characters "on a daily basis," says Alejo Benedetti, curator of the exhibition, so "we have certain assumptions about them." But "the show starts to break those characters down," by showing a dizzying array of variations that artists outside the world of comics have wrought on them.

title: Mysteries: In Search of the World That Was
summary: Ben H. Winters's "Golden State" imagines a post-apocalyptic California where lying is illegal.. 'For the facts,' goes an adage, "read history. For the truth, read fiction." These words could serve as an epigraph to Ben H. Winters's stimulating dystopian thriller "Golden State" (Mulholland, 321 pages, $28), set in an alternate version of California where all lies are illegal.

summary: Global managing partner, who has helped direct new-technology investments, begins four-year term in July. Ernst & Young has named Carmine Di Sibio, the Big Four accounting firm's global managing partner for client service, as its next global chairman and chief executive.

LOS ANGELES-The ongoing teachers' strike roiling this city is highlighting renewed support for teachers unions and traditional public schools within the Democratic Party, eclipsing a push by some party members to embrace charter schools and other education options.

title: Pentagon Identifies Three Americans Killed in Syria Bombing
summary: The blast, in the northern Syrian city of Manbij, killed four Americans this week. WASHINGTON-The Pentagon on Friday identified three of the four Americans killed in an apparent Islamic State suicide bombing in Manbij, Syria, on Wednesday.

title: U.S. Women's Soccer Wraps Camp, Faces France
summary: The first of 10 friendlies leading up to next summer's World Cup could present the toughest test for the defending champ Americans. The true diversity of America shows itself on the practice field of the U.S. Women's Soccer team. With recovery shakes.

title: Five Ways Jack Bogle Changed the World of the Everyday Investor
summary: Resume Subscription. 1. There was a time when you paid a hefty price for someone else to invest your money. Now you pay pennies on the dollar.

title: Your Bowie Is No Good Here, But He'll Pay for a Zumba Class in Brixton
summary: When you buy something in south London, there's a chance you'll get David Bowie back with your ch-ch-ch-change. One vending machine stands out in Brixton Market, a fast-gentrifying spot in south London. The prices are unusually high, £10 on the top row and £5 beneath. But then the goods for sale are unusual too: neatly rolled "Brixton pounds," with peace signs in place of zeros and singer David Bowie in place of the Queen.

title: Intel's Tough Act to Follow
summary: Chip-making giant faces several challenges following record-breaking year. TSMC has been making Intel's life difficult lately, so a small reprieve is welcome-even if it is to be short-lived.

title: Why Europeans Won't Catch Wall Street's Bandwagon
summary: Barclays aside, European lenders don't have much exposure to the areas that shone for their U.S. peers. Investors in European banks shouldn't get too excited about eye-catching results on Wall Street. Most big European lenders are more exposed to areas in which U.S. peers did badly and less to those that shone. Only Barclays could enjoy a U.S.-style bounce.

title: CVS Health Settles Pricing Fight With Walmart
summary: A split would have affected people whose employers have CVS Caremark-administered drug benefits. CVS Health Corp. and Walmart Inc. settled their fight over the cost of filling prescriptions, averting a threatened split between the health-care giant and the retail behemoth.

title: Democratic Picks for Agencies Held Up by Shutdown
summary: White House's ability to vet people for FDIC and SEC posts is strained. WASHINGTON-The Trump administration's efforts to fill some regulatory posts have hit a snag: the government shutdown.

title: Bogle's Other Financial Revolution
summary: With two mighty blows, Jack Bogle smashed an antiquated system. While Jack Bogle is known for driving down costs for investors, that still understates his contribution to finance. He should also be remembered as the inventor of total return and the mutually owned fund company.

title: Vanguard's Founder: A Force of Nature
summary: Jack Bogle played to win. Though sometimes he did it with a defibrillator handy.. Always aware of his congenital heart disease, never knowing which day would be his last, Jack Bogle drove himself-and his subordinates-hard.

title: Jason Zweig Remembers Jack Bogle
summary: 'If they can take your integrity away from you,' Vanguard's founder once growled, 'it's not integrity'. Three anecdotes about Jack Bogle stick in my memory.

title: Nissan Says Carlos Ghosn Received $8.9 Million in Improper Payments
summary: Both auto makers say they will pursue ways to recover the money. Nissan Motor Co. and Mitsubishi Motors Corp. said Carlos Ghosn improperly received nearly $9 million from a Dutch entity the car makers jointly owned, a rare public statement outlining specific allegations against the former chairman of both companies.

title: Blacture Edges Closer to Finally Launching Nearly One Year After an Introductory Super Bowl Ad
summary: Fugees co-founder Pras Michel spent big to tease his new venture, then hit snags. Pras Michel, co-founder of the hip-hop group the Fugees, advertised in last February's Super Bowl to promote Blacture, a media platform for African-American voices he expected to make live by March.

title: Utah Shows How Labor-Force Growth Fuels Economic Growth
summary: The state has outpaced the country in economic expansion since 2010. SALT LAKE CITY-Davis Smith, co-founder and CEO of Cotopaxi, an outdoor gear and apparel company, offers a glimpse of why Utah's economy is booming.

title: Labor Secretary Calls for Overhaul of Low-Skill Immigration System
summary: Alexander Acosta says process of businesses rushing to apply for visas on New Year's Day needs to change. Labor Secretary Alexander Acosta said the process businesses use to obtain visas for temporary workers needs to be fixed after the portal used to get the paperwork crashed on New Year's Day due to overwhelming demand.

title: Utah's Economy is Booming
summary: The secret behind the state's economic growth: An expanding workforce. We are delighted that you'd like to resume your subscription.

title: A Big, Fatty Opportunity for Big Pharma
summary: The next multibillion-dollar therapeutic area for drug companies may be fatty liver disease, but there are a few practical hurdles to overcome first.. The next big opportunity for pharmaceutical companies is in a disease many people don't know about.

title: Drugmakers Raise Prices Amid Shortages, Recalls
summary: Patients and pharmacies grapple with sharply higher costs for certain generic drugs. Drugmakers have sharply boosted prices of some older, low-cost prescription medicines amid supply shortages and recalls-in some cases, by threefold and more.

title: Investors Are Singing Along to 'Baby Shark'
summary: A backer of the hit Korean nursery rhyme has seen its stock almost double in just three weeks. "Baby shark, doo doo doo doo doo doo." Investors might profit from singing along, as long as they manage to stop before everyone else.

title: Is Marriott in China Barking Up the Wrong Tree?
summary: Luxury pet hotels come without the political headaches of human accommodation. Business in China can be disconcertingly political. One solution for international hotel chains might be to serve pets as well as people.

title: Malaysia's Finance Minister Wants Goldman's $7.5 Billion, Not Apology
summary: Lim Guan Eng seeks full reimbursement and reparations for the money the 1MDB fund raised with the investment bank's help. PUTRAJAYA, Malaysia-Malaysia's finance minister waved off an apology from Goldman Sachs Chief Executive David Solomon for the role of one its then-bankers in the scandal surrounding state investment fund 1Malaysia Development Bhd., saying it wasn't enough.

title: Chinese Slump Could Keep Auto Stocks Stuck in Lower Gear
summary: Industry watchers have grown gloomier about the world's largest automobile market. China's auto sales dropped 2.8% last year, their first annual decline since 1990. Even official help might not be able to get this market motoring again quickly.

title: Car Bomb at Colombian Police Academy Kills 21
summary: President Ivan Duque calls the attack in Bogotá a 'miserable terrorist act'. BOGOTÁ, Colombia-Twenty-one people were killed Thursday when a car laden with explosives burst through the gates at a police academy in Bogotá and exploded in the deadliest terrorist attack to hit the Colombian capital in more than 15 years, officials said.

title: The Aladdin: Once a Hotel, Now a Homeless Shelter
summary: Area residents say they don't see homeless people getting necessary help to move out of temporary housing. Just west of Manhattan's Times Square, across the street from a dance school and a Broadway theater, is a former hotel that houses about 300 homeless people.

title: How the Wealthy Like Jack Benny Avoided a 70% Tax Rate
summary: 'When top tax rates were high, there was always a large gap between the stated rates and what the highest earners actually paid as a percentage of their income'. It wasn't that long ago, in 1980, that America had a top income-tax rate of 70% for individuals, nearly double the current top rate of 37%.

title: Pepper...and Salt
summary: Resume Subscription. We are delighted that you'd like to resume your subscription.

title: Prosecutors Probe Hoteliers Paid by New York City to House Homeless
summary: Brothers' company is under scrutiny to determine if their businesses hid money in a potential attempt to evade taxes. Federal prosecutors in Manhattan are investigating the business practices of hotelier brothers whose legal entities New York City has paid tens of millions of dollars to house homeless New Yorkers during the past five years, according to people familiar with the matter.

title: Tribune Publishing Names New Chairman and CEO
summary: Justin Dearborn exits after a long, turbulent period for the company; his titles will be split. Tribune Publishing Co. announced Thursday that its chairman and chief executive has stepped down a little over a month after the company had rejected a takeover offer from rival McClatchy Co.

title: Carlos Ghosn to Stay in Jail After Tokyo Court Denies Bail Again
summary: Former executive's lawyer says he will make new request in court. TOKYO-Former Nissan Motor Co. Chairman Carlos Ghosn is set to stay in jail at least until March after the Tokyo District Court upheld its earlier decision to deny his release on bail.

title: Trump Has Taken Many Steps to Undermine Health Law
summary: Congress didn't repeal the Affordable Care Act but agencies have taken several steps that weaken it. The Trump administration has taken steps to undermine the Affordable Care Act since Republicans in Congress failed to repeal it.

title: Proposed ACA Rules Could Boost Costs for Millions of People
summary: Republicans say subsidies for consumers are inflated; Democrats see another effort to sabotage the health law. The Trump administration on Thursday proposed changes that could raise health insurance costs for millions of Americans who get coverage on the job or receive subsidies under the Affordable Care Act, a move that Republicans said is necessary to cut inflated subsidies but Democrats viewed as another GOP effort to sabotage the health law.

title: Apple Supplier Issues Profit Warning, Blames Weak Chinese Demand
summary: 'I've been a manager for almost half a century, but this is the first time I've seen such a large single-month drop in orders for us,' CEO says. TOKYO- Nidec Corp. , a bellwether for the global economy as a supplier of components for Apple Inc. smartphones and other consumer products, slashed its earnings forecast and blamed the U.S.-China trade conflict for a sharp slowdown in Chinese demand.

title: Army Releases a Critical History of the War in Iraq
summary: Landmark study shows the war's shortcomings, spurring worries among top officers. WASHINGTON-The Army on Thursday published a long-awaited study of the U.S. war in Iraq that criticizes decisions of some of the service's most senior officers and outlines some hard-learned lessons from the eight-year-long conflict.

title: Trump Moves to Block Pelosi's Overseas Trip Until After Shutdown
summary: Pelosi, along with other lawmakers, was set to depart Thursday on a six-day trip. WASHINGTON-President Trump postponed use of a military plane for House Speaker Nancy Pelosi to travel to Afghanistan, a day after she urged the president to delay his State of the Union address, making personal the battle over the partial government shutdown that has lasted nearly four weeks.

title: Broadway Actors' Strike Could Play a Role in Hindering Shows
summary: Union representing actors and stage managers is pushing for a share of profits. As Broadway enjoys a period of record box-office growth, Actors' Equity Association, the union representing actors and stage managers, is pushing for a piece of the profits, saying its members are a critical part of the creative process.

title: Johnson & Johnson to Use Apple Watch App for Heart-Health Study
summary: Aim is to detect the irregular heart rhythms of people living with atrial fibrillation before something life-threatening happens. Johnson & Johnson said Thursday that it has joined with Apple Inc. on a research study that will test the Apple Watch's ability to help detect early irregular heart conditions in certain people before something life-threatening happens.

title: Stocks Jump on Trade Hopes
summary: All 11 sectors in the S&P 500 rise, led by gains in trade-oriented sectors such as industrials and materials. U.S. stocks rose for a third straight session on optimism the U.S. would ratchet back tariffs on Chinese imports, a conflict that has rattled financial markets in recent months.

title: NYPD Emails Show Officers Surveilled Black Lives Matter Protesters
summary: Police gleaned intelligence on protests that followed Eric Garner's death after police put him in chokehold. The New York Police Department gained information from undercover sources embedded in the Black Lives Matter protests that swept through the city in 2015, according to hundreds of NYPD emails made public on Thursday.

title: State Department Workers Called Back to Their Jobs
summary: All employees will be paid for at two weeks; agency is unsure about future pay during the shutdown. The State Department is calling furloughed employees back to their jobs and will pay all workers for at least two weeks, finding the money despite the partial government shutdown that has cut off funding to the department for nearly four weeks.

title: New on Parents' To-Do List: Checking Kids' Credit History
summary: Resume Subscription. WASHINGTON-Parents have a new item to add to their financial to-do list: check their child's credit history.

title: 'The Birth of Loud' Review: Constructive Feedback
summary: A dual portrait of the rival inventors-one musical, the other not-who made the electric guitar the sound of modern pop. David Kirby reviews "The Birth of Loud" by Ian S. Port.. No less an authority than Beethoven is said to have called the guitar a "miniature orchestra," since it ranged over four octaves and played lush chords as well as lively melodies. Only one problem: You couldn't hear it. True, the guitar sounded fine in a parlor or around a campfire (its portability was another selling point), but as part of an ensemble or in a big hall, the limits of the guitar's usefulness were all too apparent.

title: If Weed Is Medicine, So Is Budweiser
summary: Legalize marijuana, but don't pretend it's therapeutic.. Ten states and the District of Columbia have legalized recreational marijuana use, and another eight look likely to do so in 2019. I favor the move but am troubled by the gateway to it: All these jurisdictions first passed laws permitting the use of "medical" marijuana. We should set the record straight, lest young people (and old ones) think marijuana is good for you because it is wrongly labeled a medication.

title: MTA Considers Tying Fare Hike to Service
summary: Riders increasingly are frustrated by poor subway, bus and commuter train performance. Facing intense commuter frustration over unreliable subway, bus and commuter rail services, the Metropolitan Transportation Authority is considering linking fare increases to performance goals.

title: What Bruce Ohr Told the FBI
summary: The Justice Department official's testimony raises new doubts about the bureau's honesty.. Everybody knew. Everybody of consequence at the Federal Bureau of Investigation and Justice Department understood fully in the middle of 2016-as the FBI embarked on its counterintelligence probe of Donald Trump-that it was doing so based on disinformation provided by Hillary Clinton's campaign. That's the big revelation from the transcript of the testimony Justice Department official Bruce Ohr gave Congress in August. The transcripts haven't been released, but parts were confirmed for me by congressional sources.

title: How Hinduism Has Persisted for 4,000 Years
summary: With no compulsory dogmas, the religion can reinvent itself over and over.. The word "Hindu" denotes more than a set of theological beliefs. In many languages, French and Persian among them, the word for Indian is Hindu. Originally foreigners used it when referring to the people beyond the Indus River, which is now in Islamic Pakistan. In fact, the word Hindu did not exist in any Indian language until its use by outsiders gave Indians a term for self-definition. Many Hindus, in other words, call themselves by a label that they didn't invent but adopted cheerfully.

title: Be Careful What You Wish For: Wall Street Hit by Fourth-Quarter Volatility
summary: Despite big price swings in stocks and other assets, trading revenue was down 6% among the five largest banks. Wall Street traders for years complained that they couldn't make money in calm markets. They haven't fared any better in wild ones.

title: 'Unbearable': European Firms Face Brexit Uncertainty
summary: The British Parliament's rejection of a deal to split from the EU adds pressure on European companies as they plan for an abrupt and disorderly exit. British Prime Minister Theresa May's failure to get U.K. parliamentary approval for a deal to split the country from the European Union adds significant pressure on companies as they plan for the now greater possibility of an abrupt and disorderly exit.

title: The Secrets of Jack Bogle's Investment Success
summary: The skeptics called index funds 'Bogle's folly.' They are now almost 50% of all mutual-fund assets.. When I was dean of the Yale Management School, an academic colleague came to me with an unusual request. He was planning a lecture series called "Heroes." Each month a different person would give a lecture on a heroic figure in one of a variety of fields. One lecture would exemplify the hero in politics, others in medicine, religion, the military, charitable work, etc. My colleague said, somewhat sheepishly, that the organizers were considering a lecture on "The Hero in American Business," but "they're worried that there are no heroes in business." Are there?

title: JPMorgan CEO Dimon's Compensation Tops Pre-Crisis Record
summary: Bank reported a profit of $7.07 billion, or $1.98 a share, in its latest quarterly earnings. JPMorgan Chase & Co. Chief Executive James Dimon received a compensation package valued at $31 million in 2018, up 5% from $29.5 million in 2017, according to a Thursday securities filing.

title: Martin Luther King, Colorblind Radical
summary: He flirted with democratic socialism and opposed the Vietnam War but stood against identity politics.. Monday marks Martin Luther King Jr. Day, which means it's time for the political commentariat to fight its yearly battle for King's legacy. For critics of identity politics on the left and right, King's appeals to common humanity over racial division are a rebuke not only to white supremacy but also to the racial ideology of today's progressives. In this view, King's dream of a colorblind America-where the content of our character matters more than the color of our skin-is hampered by progressives' focus on checking white privilege and stoking black grievance.

title: A 'No Deal' Brexit Can Save the European Union
summary: For the bloc to retain its democratic legitimacy, it must let the British have what they voted for.. The European Union is often accused of being an undemocratic conspiracy against its common people. Tell that to the British, who are discovering to their chagrin that sometimes the EU gives voters exactly what they say they want.
